---
title: The Buddha is a great strategy consultant for life

---

**Hello friends üíô**
===================

***Enjoy this article? Make sure to subscribe and share with friends! It‚Äôs the best way to support me üòÉ***

I‚Äôve been prepping for consultancy case interviews.

In these, you are asked something like ‚Äú*Company A wants more money to go brrrr - how can they do it?*‚Äú and you have 30 minutes to come up with a solid, airtight plan, on the fly. Or, as in a recent interview, ‚Äú*how many eggs are in the sky?*‚Äù

Approaching this without any mental models is difficult. How can you ensure your answer is logical, systematic and structured?

Thankfully, there *are* models to use!

Fundamental ones include the MECE framework (pronounced like Mr ‚ÄúMEESEEk‚Äùs) - *Mutually Exclusive Collectively Exhaustive* - and identifying root cause issues. Your approach should subdivide the nebulous problem into discrete ‚Äòbuckets‚Äô, where each bucket is completely different to the others, but collectively, all buckets cover all possible issues. For example, you can split ‚Äú*falling profits*‚Äù into two MECE buckets: *Revenue* and *Expenses* (as profit = revenue - expenses).

![GitHub - cvetanov/meeseeks-get: I'm Mr. Meeseeks! Look at me! I can get any  nested value for you from the most complex objects.](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/d9653b0a0a8cf09a91eea17b545b23ff31f36c87467e0358d6e135d22a969302/687474703a2f2f696d6730372e64657669616e746172742e6e65742f363132322f692f323031342f3035312f352f632f6d65657365656b735f62795f6d69636861656c6f676963616c6d2d6437376130666c2e706e67)When consulting on one of life‚Äôs greatest problems - *how to not suffer* - the Buddha used a MECE approach, identifying the root cause issue.

His firm, ***Buddhism***, is very popular.

His slide deck on the **'End Suffering Project'** is entitled **‚ÄòThe Four Noble Truths‚Äô**.

These were his main points.

üò≠ 1. Dukkha
===========

Sometimes, we suffer.

![Second Life Marketplace - I'm Mr. Meeseeks look at me!](data:image/jpeg;base64,)üò• 2. Samudaya
=============

The cause of suffering?

*Desire*.

We suffer when we:

1. **Want something we don‚Äôt get**: *I want abs. Each day, I wake up without abs.*
2. **Get something we don‚Äôt want**: *I get colds. A lot of the time.*

Desire is a fire that burns an endless abyss of suffering into our lives.

The flame feeds on our infinite wants, deepening the void: *I want respect; I don‚Äôt want to be poor; I want to be happy*.

ü§î 3. Nirodha
============

There is a way to end this suffering.

üòÑ 4. Magga
==========

The way to end suffering is by following the **Eight-Fold Path**.

Unfortunately, the specific details of the Eight-Fold Path require doing further work with his firm.

In a nutshell, instead of focusing on things *outside our control* (the things we get/don‚Äôt get), we focus on what we *can control*: **desire** itself.

Remove desire, remove suffering.

Also, be fully mindful of the present moment, act by the values we preach, and be truly committed to kindness towards others.

üê¨ Love Yourz
============

Nirvana *(sometimes interpreted as "blown out")* refers to extinguishing desire.1

A state without suffering or dissatisfaction; existence in pure bliss.

As another wise philosopher once said:


> *‚ÄúAlways gon' be a whip that's better than the one you got*  
> *Always gon' be some clothes that's fresher than the one's you rock*  
> *Always gon' be a bitch that's badder out there on the tours*  
> *But you ain't never gon' be happy 'til you love yours*


> *No such thing as a life that's better than yours (love yours)‚Äù*


> - **Love Yourz by J Cole**

1. *Obviously, I can‚Äôt reduce the true meaning of Nirvana to a few words.*

Peace,  
Anchit x
